speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what's been going on at school? What specific situations or people make you feel anxious or uncomfortable?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, it's just that sometimes I don't like when the teacher yells at me for not listening. And I don't like it when they tell me what to do all the time. I feel like they're trying to boss me around."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to do a behavioral observation to get a better sense of your daily interactions. Can you show me the most recent notebook or journal you've been keeping to record your feelings and experiences?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really keep a notebook, but I can tell you about the time I didn't want to play soccer in gym class because I didn't want to take turns with my friends. The teacher was trying to get us to do it, but I just didn't want to. I didn't want anyone to tell me what to do."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to take a closer look at your notebook. Can you open it up for me and point out some of the entries that have been particularly concerning or noteworthy?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think I have a notebook. Like I said, I don't really keep one. But I can tell you about that one time in class when we were supposed to be working on a project, but I just didn't want to do it, so I got in trouble. I remember feeling really mad and frustrated when the teacher said I had to do it my way, but I didn't want to. I just wanted to do it my own way."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, I see that you've been experiencing anxiety in the classroom, especially when it comes to group projects and presentations. Can you tell me more about what happens during those situations? Do you feel like you're being judged or evaluated by your peers?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really feel like I'm being judged, but sometimes I feel like everyone is watching me and waiting for me to mess up so they can say something bad about me. Like, I'll be working on a project and I'll do something wrong, and then everyone will start talking about it. It makes me feel like I'm not good enough."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your classmates and how they interact with you during group projects? Do you feel like they're pulling the weight of the project or are you feeling overwhelmed by the responsibility?



Also, have you noticed any triggers or patterns in your anxiety that seem to occur at specific times of the day or in specific environments?



And, I'd like to ask, do you have any family members or caregivers who have noticed changes in your behavior or mood?

speaker: Patient
text:
"Yeah, my friends are okay, I guess. We all work together on projects, and sometimes they help me, but sometimes they just do their own thing and don't listen to what I have to say. It's like, I'll say 'Hey, I need some help with this part' and they just ignore me. It makes me feel like I'm not important or anything."

"Uh, I don't really notice anything specific about the time of day, but it feels like it's more when we're in class and the teacher is breathing down my neck. Like, I'm just trying to do my work, but they're always telling me what to do and it's just really annoying. And sometimes it feels like they're not listening to me, you know?"

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Okay, it sounds like you're feeling quite overwhelmed in group projects. Can you tell me more about your family situation? Do you live with a single parent or multiple people, and have there been any recent changes or stressors in your home life?



Can you point out to me any specific entries in the journal that mention these stressors or changes in your home life?



Also, I'd like to take a look at your home environment, can you take me on a tour of your living space, and show me where you spend most of your time?"

speaker: Patient
text:
"Uh, I live with my mom and dad, and my little sister. We're a pretty normal family, I guess. I don't really notice anything different about my home life. We just have some stuff going on with my sister sometimes, but it's nothing big. She's always getting into my stuff, but I can handle it. We just have to share and be nice to each other."

"I don't really have a journal, like I said before. But I can tell you about the time we went to the park and my sister was being super annoying, and I just wanted to leave. I didn't want to play with her anymore because she was being so bossy. But my mom was there, and she told me it was okay and that I could take a break if I needed to."

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Thank you for sharing all of that with me. I'd like to request a thorough examination of your sleep patterns, specifically the past few nights. Can you tell me about your bedtime routine and how it's changed recently? 

Also, I'd like to take a look at your electronic devices and check for any signs of excessive screen time or online activity that might be contributing to your anxiety."

speaker: Patient
text:
"Uh, I don't really have a bedtime routine. I just go to bed when I'm tired, I guess. And my mom usually tells me to go to bed at a certain time, but sometimes I just stay up a bit later because I don't want to do my homework."

"I don't really think I have any electronic devices, but my mom has a tablet for me to do homework on sometimes. I'm not really sure what it is, but it's just a tablet with lots of stuff on it."

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Okay, thank you for sharing that with me. I'd like to do a sleep study to get a better understanding of your sleep patterns. Can you tell me about your daily routine in the morning, specifically what time you wake up and how long it takes you to get ready for school?



Also, do you have any favorite activities or hobbies that you enjoy doing in the morning, or are you more of a morning person or a night owl?"



"

speaker: Patient
text: "Uh, I wake up pretty early, I guess. My mom says I have to be up by 6:30 or 7:00 am to get ready for school. I like to eat breakfast, and then I grab my backpack and head out the door. I don't really have any favorite activities in the morning, I just kind of do whatever my mom tells me to do. I like playing outside during recess, though."

speaker: Doctor
text:

speaker: Patient
text:
"Uh, I don't really think I've noticed any changes in my appetite, but I do get really hungry sometimes during the day. And I usually eat lunch at school, so I'm not really sure if I'm eating too much or too little. I just kind of eat what my mom packs for me, I guess."

"I don't really think I have trouble falling asleep, but sometimes I do lie awake at night thinking about stuff that happened in class. Like, I'll be lying in bed and I'll be thinking about what the teacher said or what happened with my friends, and it just makes me feel really frustrated and worried. I don't know, it's just hard to explain."

"I don't really have my school records with me, but I can tell you about my grades. I'm doing okay, I guess. I'm not really sure if I'm doing well or not, though. I just kind of do my work and hope I get by, you know

speaker: Doctor
text:
"I see that you've been experiencing changes in your appetite and energy levels. Can you tell me more about that? Are you eating more or less than usual, and do you find that you have more or less energy to do your schoolwork?



Also, I'd like to request a review of your school records, I'd like to see your grades and report card from the last semester, can you bring them with you to our next appointment?
